newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan ministers quit ahead of reshuffle.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan ministers quit ahead of reshuffle.

text.p: Three Taiwan ministers resigned on Thursday, increasing pressure on the government ahead of a planned cabinet reshuffle triggered by public discontent over rising crime on the island.

Ma Ying-jeou, minister without portfolio and a popular politican, Interior Minister Lin Feng-cheng, and Tjiu Mau-ying, chairman of Taiwan's Council of Agriculture, all tendered their resignations to Premier Lien Chan.

The unexpected resignations caught the ruling Nationalist Party and Lien's administration by surprise. The administration, which has faced intense criticism over a spate of violent crime, was expected to announce a reshuffle next week.

Ma appeared to take a swipe at Taiwan's political culture in his resignation statement, saying he stepped down "due to a change of political ethics, obstacles in reforms and growing public discontent."
He also accused unnamed officials of "struggling for power, taking credit and shunning responsibility."
Lin had been under fire over the island's crime wave, which culminated in the kidnap and murder of the teenage daughter of renowned actress Pai Ping-ping.
Last month, the body of 17-year-old Pai Hsiao-yen was found floating naked in a river. Police said she had been kidnapped and murdered. The killers remained at large.
The murder was the latest in a number of high-profile violent crimes to hit Taiwan beginning last year.
More than 50,000 people marched in Taipei on Sunday to protest against the government's failure to stop crime and demand Lien's resignation and a cabinet reshuffle.

Tjiu has been under fire since March for the Council of Agriculture's failure to prevent the outbreak of a deadly epidemic of hog foot-and-mouth disease that forced Taiwan to ban pork exports, jeopardising the island's economic recovery.
The protest over crime prompted President Lee Teng-hui, who doubles as chairman of the Nationalist Party, to call for a partial reshuffle of the cabinet on Wednesday.

Lien, who had tendered his resignation to Lee, was asked to stay on. But Lee asked the premier, who is also vice president, to deliver a list of reshuffled cabinet positions for approval during next Wednesday's central standing committee meeting.
State media had speculated that Lin would be asked to step down and be replaced by the popular Ma.
Opposition parties said a partial government reshuffle was not enough.

Lawmakers from the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party and the opposition New Party sought support for a motion asking President Lee to call for a complete cabinet reshuffle and to replace Lien.
"Public discontent is boiling. We want President Lee to name a new premier," Chen Chung-hsin, deputy secretary-general of the Democratic Progressive Party, told Reuters in a telephone interview.
"The public has demanded a change. The ruling Nationalist Party cannot ignore the voice of the people," Chen said.
Analysts forecast the island's hypersensitive stock market would nose-dive on Friday on fears of political upheaval.
"Local politics is expected to be unstable and uncertainty is the market's biggest enemy," said Alex Chan, an analyst of HSBC James Capel.
